text: Seventy-ninth session
Agenda item 163 (a)
Financing of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Middle East: United Nations Disengagement Observer Force
Budget for the United Nations Disengagement Observer Force for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026
Report of the Secretary-General
Contents
Mandate and planned results
A.	Overall

The mandate of the United Nations Disengagement Observer Force (UNDOF) was established by the Security Council in its resolution 350 (1974). The most recent extension of the mandate was authorized by the Council in its resolution 2766 (2024), by which the Council extended the mandate until 30 June 2025.
The Force is mandated to help the Security Council to achieve the overall objective, namely, to maintain international peace and security.

Within this overall objective, UNDOF will, during the budget period, contribute to a number of expected accomplishments by delivering related key outputs, shown in the frameworks below. These frameworks are organized according to components (operations and support), which are derived from the mandate of the Force.

The expected accomplishments would lead to the fulfilment of the objective of the Security Council within the lifetime of the Force, and the indicators of achievement show a measurement of progress towards such accomplishments during the budget period. The human resources requirements of UNDOF, in terms of the number of personnel, have been attributed to the individual components, with the exception of the executive direction and management of the Force, which can be attributed to the Force as a whole. Variances in the number of personnel, compared with the approved budget for the 2024/25 period, have been explained under the relevant components.

The headquarters of UNDOF is located in Camp Faouar on the Bravo side and its logistics base is located in Camp Ziouani on the Alpha side (Israeli-occupied Golan). UNDOF will maintain its 17 positions in the area of operations: 7 in the northern part of the area of separation, 5 in the central part and 4 in the southern part of the area of operations, as well as 1 position on the Alpha side, and the Charlie gate.
B.	Planning assumptions and mission support initiatives

The Force has, in general, maintained the ceasefire between Israel and the Syrian Arab Republic, albeit in a continuously volatile environment attributable to the continued violations of the Agreement on Disengagement between Israeli and Syrian Forces of 1974 by the parties and amid regional escalation. UNDOF liaison with the parties continues to be crucial in ensuring that the parties uphold their obligations under the terms of the Disengagement Agreement to maintain the ceasefire and prevent further violations and escalation of the situation across the ceasefire line.

The Force will continue the implementation of its mandated observation activities from its positions, on both the Alpha and Bravo sides, and patrolling activities from Camp Ziouani and from Camp Faouar into the area of separation. UNDOF will enhance its liaison with both sides to ensure that there is no military personnel or activity in the area of separation and that they accord UNDOF the freedom of movement in conducting its mandated activities safely and securely. The area of separation is approximately 80 km in length from north to south and varies in width from 12.5 km along the crest of Mount Hermon in the north to less than 400 m along the border between the Syrian Arab Republic and Jordan.

The Force will continue to carry out its mandated inspections on both the Alpha and Bravo sides, liaising with both parties in all sectors of the respective sides of the areas of limitation, and the restoration, including the refurbishment and painting, of the barrels marking the ceasefire line and the Bravo line, conditions permitting. In addition, UNDOF will continue the implementation of quick-impact projects as a confidence-building measure.

The Force will continue to undertake the clearance of mines, unexploded ordnance and improvised explosive devices from the areas of separation to ensure the safety of its personnel. In line with the priorities of Action for Peacekeeping Plus to further improve the safety and security of mission personnel in an integrated manner, UNDOF will continue to implement measures in that regard.
Mission support initiatives
With regard to mission support, in the 2025/26 period, the Force will refurbish one observation position.

The proposed budget for the 2025/26 period includes six projects with an estimated cost of $970,000 for the continuous refurbishment and upgrading of roads and the repairing of fences and snow poles. Moreover, UNDOF will continue the implementation of its environmental projects, such as the installation of solar power systems, in order to enhance the self-sufficiency of all its positions while reducing its carbon footprint in line with the Organization’s environmental strategy. The efficiency gains of UNDOF can be fully credited to this initiative through decreased electricity usage from the national grid on the Alpha side and a reduction in fuel consumption by approximately 220,000 litres on the Bravo side.

The proposed civilian staffing complement for UNDOF consists of 145 posts and positions and includes four targeted staffing changes in the areas of supply chain management and facilities management. These changes are designed to enhance the mission’s capacity to handle evolving operational challenges in these critical sectors.

The estimated resource requirements for the maintenance and operation of the mission for the 2025/26 financial period reflect increased requirements under: (a) military contingents, attributable primarily to the higher cost of rotation of military contingents; and (b) civilian personnel, attributable primarily to the introduction of danger pay for the Alpha side and the application of a lower vacancy rate of 0 per cent compared with 50 per cent in the approved budget for 2024/25 for general temporary assistance positions. The increased requirements are offset in part by decreased requirements under operational costs, owing mainly to a reduction in requirements for freight and the acquisition of vehicles due to the vehicle replacement plan that occurred in the 2023/24 financial period and efficiencies arising from the transfer of assets from the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA).
C.	Regional mission cooperation

UNDOF will continue to ensure coordination with other United Nations peacekeeping missions in the region, namely, the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO), the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) and the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP), to address issues of regional interest.
UNDOF will continue to maintain operational control of the UNTSO military observers serving in the Observer Group Golan and liaise with the UNTSO liaison office in Damascus, as required.

UNDOF will continue to be supported by UNIFIL in logistics for the movement of its goods and personnel through Lebanon, as well as for information technology and communications services. Through the coordination of the Regional Field Technology Section, UNIFIL provides UNDOF with strategic management for the coordination and implementation of field technology services, with the aim of reducing service disparities, producing economies of scale and eliminating duplication of effort among the peacekeeping missions in the region. UNIFIL also provides support on conduct and discipline matters to UNDOF, including the provision of briefings and training with respect to the prevention of sexual exploitation and sexual abuse, sexual harassment and fraud, as well as on the prevention of prohibited conduct.

UNDOF will continue to provide administrative support to the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria, in the Force’s capacity as the United Nations house bank for the Syrian Arab Republic, as well as for procurement services and financial services, on a cost-recovery basis.

In addition, UNDOF will continue to be supported by the Kuwait Joint Support Office, where one General Service staff is embedded, for the processing of payroll for the Force’s national staff and individual uniformed personnel.

Human resources: Office of the Head of Mission/Force Commander

UNDOF continues to require the international temporary position of Military Liaison Officer (P-4) to ensure continuity of liaison and coordination responsibilities within the Office of the Head of Mission/Force Commander and to ensure effective coordination and communication in the implementation of the Comprehensive Planning and Performance Assessment System. The Military Liaison Officer oversees and guides the maintenance of daily liaison with the parties to the 1974 Disengagement of Forces Agreement and makes strategic and operational recommendations to senior management on all liaison issues of concern. The incumbent will maintain contacts and coordination with United Nations counterparts and local embassies, including troop-contributing countries, to address queries about operations of UNDOF. The Military Liaison Officer also serves as a focal point in the Office of the Head of Mission/Force Commander to ensure effective coordination in implementing Action for Peacekeeping Plus priorities.

Human resources: Integrated Warehouse and Life Support Section

The Integrated Warehouse and Life Support Section provides the Force with life support items, such as rations, water and fuel, as well as other goods and services considered critical. In the context of the ongoing organizational shift towards more standardized professional categories, it is proposed that the post of Supply Officer (Field Service), shown in table 5, be reclassified to Chief of Supply Chain Management (P-4), to ensure continuity regarding the provision of life support for UNDOF personnel.

The Supply Officer position at the FS-7 level is part of a legacy job profile that is gradually being phased out across the United Nations and replaced by a professional job profile, in order to attract a larger pool of candidates with global and strategic supply chain management experience. The functions performed by Field Service staff at the FS-7 level is equated to the P-4 level in terms of post classification and cost, which represents an increase of $7,800 annually at current rates.

In addition, it is proposed that the post of Administrative Assistant, shown in table 5, be reassigned as Rations Assistant, to support critical operations within the Rations Unit, including the inspection of rations packs, the analysis of stock balance, the rotation and issuance of rations packs and bottled water, and ensuring that accurate and complete accounting and reporting are functioning and that all relevant records are maintained. The reassignment will also ensure operational continuity and avoid the overreliance on a single staff member.
Table 6
Human resources: Facilities Management Unit

The Facilities Management Unit is responsible for ensuring that all facilities are maintained to standard. The work involves a comprehensive range of services, including repairs, cleaning, utilities management and space optimization to meet operational needs. In order to enhance effective control of the fuel consumption reduction due to the implementation of solar power system installation, as well as to record and analyse the fuel consumption in a timely manner, it is proposed that a post of Telecommunications Technical Assistant, shown in table 6, be reassigned as Facilities Management Assistant to support the mission-wide installation of facility monitoring systems.
The functions related to the post of Telecommunications Technical Assistant will be absorbed within existing capacities.
Table 7
Human resources: Engineering Section

In order to continue the implementation of projects in the areas of energy efficiency, solar power systems and waste management and the maintenance and/or refurbishment of positions, UNDOF will continue to require the position of Engineering Officer (P-3) for the 2025/26 period. The responsibilities include the preparation of administrative and technical documents related to the design, structural calculation, electrical supply, water supply and technical evaluation for the bidding process to ensure that the selected vendors adhere to United Nations specifications.

In addition, the Engineering Officer is responsible for coordinating requirements across all components of the Force and for supervising a team of staff members from diverse occupational groups, such as plumbing, carpentry and metalwork. The Engineering Officer is also responsible for monitoring the progress of construction and environmental projects to ensure that the facilities are available under adequate operational conditions, in line with the priorities set out under Action for Peacekeeping Plus.
Table 8
Human resources: Transport Section

The Transport Section provides the Force with safe, efficient and timely movement of equipment, supplies and personnel. In the context of the ongoing organizational shift towards more standardized professional categories, it is proposed that the post of Chief of Transport (Field Service), shown in table 8, be reclassified to Chief of Transport (P-4), to ensure operational continuity.

The Chief of Transport post at the FS-7 level is part of a legacy job profile that is gradually being phased out across the United Nations and replaced by a professional job profile, in order to attract a larger pool of candidates with global and strategic transport management experience. The functions performed by Field Service staff at the FS-7 level is equated to the P-4 level in terms of post classification and cost, which represents an increase of $7,800 annually at current rates.
Evaluation activities

No evaluations were completed at UNDOF during the 2023/24 period. A military capability study was planned by the Department of Peace Operations; however, due to the current security situation, it was postponed until further notice.

Analysis of variances

The increased requirements are attributable primarily to the higher cost of rotations for military contingents due to the need for alternative rotation routes for the Bravo side through Damascus airport. The increased requirements are offset in part by reduced requirements owing to the lower cost of the mission subsistence allowance for military staff officers based on the revised rates effective 1 January 2025, compared with the rates applied in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period.

The increased requirements are attributable primarily to: (a) the application of the higher salary rates based on the revised scale, compared with the rates applied in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period; and (b) the introduction of danger pay for the Alpha side, as from April 2024.

The increased requirements are attributable primarily to the application of the higher average level/step of the salary scale based on the current staffing establishment, compared with the level/step applied in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period.
The increased requirements are attributable primarily to the application of the lower vacancy rate of 0.0 per cent, compared with 50.0 per cent applied in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period.
The increased requirements are attributable primarily to daily subsistence allowance for the weekly travel of drivers to new supply collection points, due to the closure of regular supply routes.

The reduced requirements are attributable to: (a) the lower estimated average price of fuel for generators of $0.981 per litre for 1.6 million litres, compared with $1.061 per litre for 1.7 million litres included in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period and the lower requirements for operation and maintenance fees; and (b) the lower estimated consumption of electricity on the Alpha side resulting from the continued implementation of solar power systems. The decreased requirements are offset in part by increased requirements relating to the cost of cleaning services, which were previously budgeted under individual contractual services.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to: (a) the reduction in requirements for the acquisition of vehicles due to the vehicle replacement plan that occurred in the 2023/24 period and efficiencies arising from the transfer of forklifts and utility vehicles from MINUSMA; and (b) the lower estimated average price of fuel for vehicles of $0.981 per litre for 0.5 million litres, compared with $1.061 per litre for 0.6 million litres included in the approved budget for the 2024/25 period.
The increased requirements are attributable primarily to the replacement of firewalls and the renewal of licensing requirements.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to a reduction in the requirements for individual contractors, due to: (a) the outsourcing of the camp cleaning contract, for which provisions are included under maintenance services in facilities and infrastructure; and (b) lower costs for freight of vehicles owing to the vehicle replacement plan which occurred in the 2023/24 period.
Actions to be taken by the General Assembly
The actions to be taken by the General Assembly in connection with the financing of the United Nations Disengagement Observer Force are:
Appropriation of the amount of $70,100,900 for the maintenance of the Force for the 12-month period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026;
Assessment of the amount in subparagraph (a) above at a monthly rate of $5,841,742 should the Security Council decide to continue the mandate of the Force.
